definition: modal particle
dialect/language/speech
to tell to
gas/air/smell/weather/to make angry/to annoy/to get angry/vital energy/qi
to help/to assist
word/statement/speech/lyrics/CL:組|组[zu3],個|个[ge4]/a form of lyric poetry, flourishing in the Song dynasty 宋朝|宋朝[Song4 chao2]/CL:首[shou3]

sentences.english: The basic function of the Cantonese final particles is assisting the intonation to convey moods.
sentences.chinese: 廣州話句末語氣助詞的基本功能是輔助句調錶達語氣。

sentences.english: Chinese modal particles are meant to add supplementary meanings to the affective meaning of a sentence.
sentences.chinese: 語氣助詞的本質意義在於附加句子的情感意義。

definition: to talk nonsense/to bullshit
A rabbit doesn't eat the grass by its own burrow (idiom); One shouldn't do anything to harm one's neighbors.
pinyin: tu4 zi5 bu4 chi1 wo1 bian1 cao3

definition: to ask a question, already knowing the answer
sb who goes whichever way the wind blows/sb with no mind of their own/easily swayed person/opportunist
overtones in conversation/things indirectly implied from what is said
all crows are black (idiom)/evil people are bad all over the world
pinyin: tian1 xia4 wu1 ya1 yi1 ban1 hei1

definition: vain
lit. in the eyes of a lover appears 西施[Xi1 shi1] (idiom); fig. beauty is in the eye of the beholder
pinyin: qing2 ren2 yan3 li3 chu1 Xi1 shi1

definition: conjoined twins
foolish talk/nonsense
lit. to gnaw a book/to study/to cram
Every family goes through its problems. (idiom)
pinyin: jia1 jia1 you3 ben3 nan2 nian4 de5 jing1

definition: lit. to swell one's face up by slapping it to look imposing (idiom); to seek to impress by feigning more than one's abilities
pinyin: da3 zhong3 lian3 chong1 pang4 zi5

definition: see the opportunity and act (idiom); to act according to circumstances/to play it by ear/to use one's discretion
see 領盒飯|领盒饭[ling3 he2 fan4]
lit. 300 silver taels not hidden here (idiom); fig. to reveal what one intends to hide
pinyin: ci3 di4 wu2 yin2 san1 bai3 liang3
